headline: Carnitas - Pressure Cooker
description: Cook pork shoulder in an Instant Pot for savory pork carnitas. Pork butt is pressure-cooked to tender shreds with onion, garlic, orange, and spices.

video.description: Tender and savory pork carnitas cooked in a pressure cooker!
video.name: Carnitas- Pressure Cooker

name: Carnitas - Pressure Cooker
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons olive oil, or more to taste
4 cloves garlic, diced, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Trim excess fat from pork butt; cut pork into 2-inch cubes and transfer to a large bowl.

Combine salt, oregano, cumin, black pepper, chile powder, and paprika in a small bowl. Rub pork cubes with spice mixture. Coat seasoned pork cubes lightly in olive oil; transfer to a pressure cooker. Cover pork cubes with orange juice, onion, and garlic.
Place lid on the pressure cooker and lock; bring to full pressure over medium heat until pork is no longer pink in the center, about 60 minutes. Let pressure come down naturally, about 15 minutes.
Remove pork from the pressure cooker and shred meat.

review.reviewBody: Made it exactly as written and used for smothered burritos. It was out of this world. This is the first time I’ve ever rated a recipe. That’s how good it was! Everyone loved it
Excellent spice mixture. Wouldn't change anything. This gives a mild, yet spicy taste too. Don't change spice mixture, just adjust accordingly with them.

We are making this again for SuperBowl today and it is fantastic! We are from California and carnitas there is like a religion, and this hits the mark. To Donna G who whined about the spices for her ONE POUND of meat being too salty, please read and follow the recipe before making a negative review, which calls for a 6lb pork shoulder. You using 6xs the salt called for is not the posters problem. :)

Yum! The juice from this is so good you will want to drink it! I just can't bring myself to toss it out. I think I may marinate some chicken in it. The meat was so tender. I have a ninja foodi and after it was done, I drained the meat, saved the liquid, and added the meat back into the pot. I set it to 400 degrees to airfry to get those crispy bits. Delicious!!!!
Surprisingly good. Seemed like a simple recipe. We used this pork in burritos, tacos, and fajitas over a month's time. We froze it in quart bags and used it as we needed it. I'll make this again.
The best and easiest carnitas recipe I have found. My family loves it. I will serve over rice or in a flour tortilla. Leftovers are great in a quesadilla. So delicious.
It was super easy to do and very tasty..
My family and I love it! We like it hot, so throw in some diced jalapeño pepper and chili flakes. It freezes SO well too!
I've been experimenting with my own Carnitas recipe for 10 years, and this one is perfect with a pressure cooker
This was super simple and very delicious.
It took longer to cook in my Instant Pot but the results were fabulous. I would make it again and probably use less salt since I think my roasts are smaller in size.
This recipe was so flavorful and absolutely delicious. The pork melts in your mouth. I made this as written but added the juice of a couple of limes. Definitely a keeper, thanks!

Sorry... The picture looks bit awful. I have already had more than half of it I made. I was craving tacos so I finally cooked it, which is my first trial. I was very impressed on this recipe because this carnitas reminds me of ones I had in Cali. I decided to make a lot for stock so that I can eat them anytime I want! Very good recipe:)

Wow- this rivaled true Puerto Rican pernil and is WAYYYY easier. I reduced the orange juice as others suggested but otherwise made it as it. I've used it for nachos, cuban sandwiches, and just to eat staight. I couldn't find a small pork butt at the store one of the times I made this, so I used a pork loin roast and it came out just as good.

Such a wonderful recipe! I cooked onions & various color peppers with some of the remaining liquid. So very tasty. My husband said it was better than a restaurant! Thanks so much for sharing this recipe.
I love this. I always add 3 chopped jalapenos and use tangerine juice from y backyard. Got to love California
Loved it. Only did 2.5 lbs of pork, kept all of the other ingredient measurements. Added juice of 1 squeezed lime.
This is a keeper! My picky family gobbled these tacos right up. I would note that garlic cloves are necessary and should not be substituted by jarred minced garlic as it is necessary for the flavor.

I made this with 2 pounds of pork shoulder. I cut the salt in half and then added a teaspoon of turmeric and coriander. I cooked it for 30 minutes on medium and it came out perfect! It also gave me plenty of sauce left over to freeze for future use. I'm thinking an enchilada sauce later. Great recipe!
This was absolutely delicious and super fast in the instant pot! Followed all directions and it was perfection to say the least. You need to make this!

This turned out well, but I did feel that the spices were not enough, it was a little bland. Delicious, don’t get me wrong, just felt it could have used a little more spice. With the fixings on top, it was delicious!
This came out good. It was tender, flavorful, and fell apart very nicely. Definitely a make-again for us.
Absolutely amazing and super easy!!! I love this recipe. It turns out great every time!
Good recipe. I agree with tcasa that 1 cup.of orange juice is enough. Too juicy. I let my pork cubes sit in the fridge overnight with the dry spices on them. Flavor held up.
This is a wonderfully easy recipe to get right. The flavors are spot-on.
Very good! The next night we turned the pork into cajun pork stew and that was amazing! A perfect segue!
Came out amazing. Makes fantastic street tacos

Disappointed! Reading all the reviews I was sure this would be wonderful. Although the seasonings were good it was way too much for 1 lb. of meat....not only that 1.5 TBLS of salt...wow! Going to try again with half the salt & will double the meat.

This was wonderful. I have an 8qt Instant Pot so I used 1 1/2 cups of fresh orange juice and then cooked it down after the meat was cooked. We like spicy so next time I will kick up the spices and add some jalapenos too. thanks for a great recipe.

I had a pork butt that needed to be cooked asap in the fridge and used this recipe in my instant pot. This just came out of the pressure cooker at 10:30 pm and we can’t stop eating it if that says anything. I added a teaspoon of coriander and didn’t have orange juice so I squeezed some mandarin oranges into chicken broth and used that. The flavor is so amazing that I skimmed the fat off the top and will use the juice for posole tomorrow.

My roast was only 2.75 pounds but I did not adjust the seasonings because I know that you lose flavor in the IP. I did adjust the OJ down to 3/4 cup but was still able to get this to pressure. 

After I shredded it the meat, I put it under the broiler for a few minutes to dry it a bit and get some crispy edges. I definitely recommend this step.

This was very excellent and will probably be in regular rotation. It's perfect for inside tacos, enchiladas or even tamales.

It turned out juicy and delicious which wasn't true for the last two recipes I tried. Definitely a keeper! I kept my alterations minimal - I let the pork marinade in the spices overnight (saw the comment about spices washing off), added a bit of coriander, increased garlic (we love it in this house and cooked for 40 mins since I was using a little over 3 lbs. Thank you for sharing the recipe!

Made this for the first time in our new Ninja Foodi, came out awesome. When reheating leftovers I put them in a pan and crisped them up a bit, love the texture of the crispy edges. Next time I think I'm going to air fry the meat a bit once pressure cooking is done. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

An excellent recipe. Next time however, I
Will completely omit salt.
Absolutely delicious! I had my doubts about the orange juice, but it was so tender and flavorful! SO DELICIOUS
Excellent - will make again

Great recipe! Fast and easy prep that will feed 6 people with plenty for leftovers (I freeze a portion for those evenings where you don’t feel like making another meal).

I haven’t felt the need to make any changes to ingredients but sometimes I will spread a portion on a cooking tray and pop it under the broiler for a couple of minutes, for those that like it a little crispy on the edges.
First time I made this, as directed, turned out perfectly. It was tender and delicious.
Outstanding. After I shredded it, I put it under the broiler to crisp it up. So amazingly flavorful and tender.

This was honestly amazing. It’s not often that I can say I made something that tastes as flavorful and authentic as my favorite taco truck. I used about 2 lbs of meat, but only cut the seasonings in half for a little extra flavor. As suggested, I added 1 tsp of coriander and I felt like the flavor came through very nicely. I didn’t have any orange juice on hand, so I used 1/4 cup of apple cider vinegar. It added the acidity necessary and I honestly didn’t notice the difference. When it was finished cooking, I shredded the meat and broiled it in the oven for a few minutes to get it nice and crispy. Looking forward to making this again very soon!

This is such a great recipe!! It’s my go to for pork carnitas. I do make one small change. At the end after shredding, I add the meat to a sheet pan and broil in the middle of the oven for 5 minutes. After 5 minutes I mix up the meat and bast with juices and put it back in the oven for another 5 minutes, then serve.
Best carnitas ever

I added 1 tsp of coriander like suggested to the seasonings when cooking the meat. After the meat was cooked and shredded I added it back to the juice in the pot and added 1 7oz can of mild diced green chillies not drained and 1 20oz can of pineapple tidbits drained. Let it cook for 45 minutes on slow cooker mode.

This turned out so good! I made it for my husbands 40th birthday get together, and everyone was raving about it. I made a couple of changes based on what other readers had mentioned. I added a teaspoon of coriander and I browned the pork chunks before adding to my instant pot. I also increased the time a bit since I had a bit more meat. It turned out perfect! I will definitely be making it again! Thank you for sharing!
Wonderful recipe. To bring up the flavor profile I roasted the spices before rubbing them on the meat, then set the meat in the fridge for a couple hours before adding to pressure cooker.

This was great I added the other reviewers suggestion also it’s missing the Mexican coke which is added when putting under the broiler to make crispiest, the Mexican coke is the old timey glass bottle real sugar coke. This recipe was fantastic and only 1 1/2 hrs from start to finish, not the all day affair.
The whole family loved the Carnitas. After I shredded the pork I put it in a frying pan to brown the edges.
So easy and tastes so good!

Great recipe! My whole family loved this. I added ground coriander, as many suggested and it was awesome. I might make it with less liquid next time. I used the Ninja Foodi which doesn't have a MED pressure setting, I did low for 1 hour, it was perfect. Soft and perfectly seasoned.

OMG!! These were so good! Our pork butt was 7+ lbs so I increased the seasonings and OJ a tad to accommodate. I also sprinkled in some coriander as others suggested. We didn't need to shred ours as it was mostly in small tender cubes. Just perfect. Served with black beans (add some of the carnita juice to the beans!), guacamole, and pickled red onions.
Loved the recipe, except it was a little overly salty, next time no additional salt.

I've made this several times now in my Instant Pot and it is delicious to us! I scaled the recipe down recently as I had a small roast (~2.5 lbs), but I left the amount of Chile powder (used ancho chili powder), paprika, and garlic the same--just wanted more of those flavors than less of that day. Recommendation on 6qt IP is to use 1 cup liquid, but I used 1/2 cup OJ + 1/4 cup lime juice and it came out perfect. As make ahead meal, shredded meat and stored in container. Strained and reserved juices from IP into another container to add a little to baking dish to reheat in oven, covered, 275-300F and broil in last few minutes to crisp up meat a little. Perfect for my tacos and enchilada dinners! Thank you for the recipe!

This taste outstanding! I will definitely be making it again. I changed it a little: I used more garlic, reduced the salt to 1 tbs, I omitted the olive oil, I forgot to cut into cubes so I cooked in slow cooker for 6 hrs, shredded meat and returned to juice on warm for 60 minutes. This is the best ever carnitas!!
Impressed my son. Followed the recipe exactly

So good! if using the Instant pot only cook for about 35 min. If you cook longer the orange juice will not be enough liquid and you'll have burnt or in my case nicely caramelized meat. a bit longer and it would have burned. Great flavor!

I did a ten pound roast and I trimmed the outside fat but kept the bone in. Sauté for 30 minutes and pressure cooked for two hours. I put one small clementine in with the skin and it gave a nice flavor with onion and garlic on the bottom of the pan.

This was AMAZING! I didn’t pay attention to the size of roast the recipe called for so mine was only 2-1/2 pounds. I decreased the salt but kept all the other seasonings the same and it was perfect! Instead of fresh onions and garlic, I used powder. After it cooked in the pressure cooker, I toasted up the meat and raw onion in a cast iron pan in some oil and served it on corn tortillas that I toasted on the open flame of the gas stove and topped with fresh pico and avocado! Perfection! I’m definitely saving this recipe and will stick to the higher spice to meat ratio.

This was really good and gave me a great opportunity to use the pressure cooker instead of the slow cooker warming up my kitchen all day when it's 90 degrees outside. I did add coriander as others did, a quick saute and then 40 minutes in the pressure cooker before a quick release. The tacos were even more excellent topped with Cabbage Pico de Gallo recipe also from this site. Will make again!
The BEST pork carnitas recipe I’ve ever had/made.
Delicious! Would be great for a taco bar and entertaining!
it was so delicious! Very juicy and flavorful!

Absolutely delicious!! Made it just as the recipe reads and it is as good as any I have ever ordered in a restaurant. Fork tender, it shredded just by pressing the fork against it. It is juicy and oh so flavorful

This recipe was absolutely delicious. My whole family liked it. I was amazed at how tender the pork was. It fell apart on its own when pulling it out of the pressure cooker. Shredding was super easy. This was my first time making Carnitas. I scaled the recipe for a 3 lb Boston Butt Roast and set the pressure cooker for 45 min with natural release for 15 minutes. I also added 1 tsp of coriander as others suggested. Other than that I made it as written. We had it 2 ways. I made up the other ingredients and made a carnitas salad bowl like at Chipotle, and my son had carnitas tacos. Both great. I highly recommend his recipe.

Made this for the first time tonight, delicious! The entire family loved it, even our pickiest eater! I followed the recipe exactly, the only additional thing I did was broil the shredded pork in the oven at the end on high for about 5-8 minutes to crisp things up. (Be sure and add some of the juice to the pan to keep things moist) So good and will be making again! This would be a great one for company!

TIP-- put these under the broiler for a few minutes to add some crispiness, amazing how they come out without having to fry them!

Amazing, great flavor. I use ~3.5 ish pound pork butt and leave the rest of the recipe as is.
Yum!
Meat was perfect! I used the basic spices they recommended within what I had on hand. Will definitely make again.
Fantastic! I didn’t have orange juice but substituted apple juice and it was so good I will use apple juice from here on out. Perfectly cooked and shredded easily. My whole family loved it!

This is fabulous. I added the coriander that people suggested and I let the meat marinate in the spice mixture for a few hours. I also substituted grapefruit juice (fresh) because I didn’t have OJ. I made a sugar/vinegar coleslaw to go on top. I would love cilantro on it too. Just none at home.
It was awesome seasonings were perfect! I used the liquid that was left to make a BBQ sauce. I used a 3 lb pork butt.
awesome. i cut the salt back a little and it still tasted amazing! thanks for sharing this recipe.
Delicious! I used my InstantPot. It was easy, fast and the taste was amazing.
Absolutely amazing! Followed the recipe exactly and it was amazing. Will definitely be making this again. :)

Cut an almost four pound butt into 1-3 inch pieces keeping all the lovely fat on; cooked only 45 minutes under pressure with only spices and a squirt of lime juice. After 15 minutes of depressurization I added diced onion and simmered out the remaining water for 20 minutes leaving a wonderfully rich and flavorful pork that shredded easily by mere stirring. No need to crisp in the oven.
The seasonings are subtle - hold back on the salt. The pastured pork flavor and mouthfeel are sublime. I served it in tortillas with some pickled red onion, roasted diced poblano, and crumbled feta.
I browned the meat using the saute feature and cooked for 45 minutes. There were no leftovers! This is going in our favorite recipes drawer.

i had a 3 lb pork butt so I halved all the seasonings except chile and the orange juice. The 1/2 t chile seems really light anyway. I used a gallon ziplock to "rub the pork with the seasonings" and oiled in the same bag after that. I browned my pork chunks before adding the juice and cooking. I added 3/4 t coriander per other reviews. Like others I broiled it afterwards for a bit leaving the juices in the pressure cooker. Good and very easy. I also only cooked 45 minutes since it was a smaller roast.
This is so good! I followed the recipe as written, with the exception of transferring the meat onto a sheet pan after shredding and broiling for a few minutes to get some crunch.
OMGeeee fabulous!!!! Sooo tender & packed with flavor. Did exactly as recipe stated except didn't use any oil.

It was my first time cooking pork butt. The meat turned out incredibly TENDER! I really liked the seasoning + a tsp of coriander. I did not add orange juice as I like to cook healthily and avoid unnecessary sugars. Instead of orange juice, I added a cup of water (which ended up a lot because the meat produced a lot of juices). I also sautéed the meat and onion before pressurizing it to bring out the flavors. The meat tastes absolutely delicious! My husband liked it a lot as well.
All I changed was using concentrated lemon and lime, since I forgot to pickup orange juice from the grocery store. This is awesome and I’ll be making it again.
I made this recipe exactly like it is written by the author. The pork was very tender and tasty. The pork goes well in burrito tortillas, in taco shells, on tostadas, etc.

Didn't make any changes, I am going to try to pan fry the results of this and see if I can get it crispy, the flavor is good, though next time I might add a little more spice (maybe some red pepper). Overall, quite tasty!
So good. Full of flavor. Super easy.

IF MAKING IN A TRADITIONAL PRESSURE COOKER, BE SURE TO ADD QUITE A BIT OF WATER OR IT WILL BURN. It burned twice on me. Despite a slightly burnt taste,it was good. If it hadn’t burned, I probably could have rated the recipe as 5 stars.
I added achiote. Next time I will add lime juice as suggested by another reviewer. So easy, so delicious!
Kids love this. Easy, quick and ample.
My first ever Insta-pot dish. It was so good my husband asked which restaurant I bought it from. Thanks for sharing.
Followed recipe exactly. Came out perfect! I’ve made this several times now for my family and they love it! Great dinner for week night.

Would have given 5 stars but it is WAY WAY too much salt. Really only need a teaspoon or two for this amount of meat. I used less orange juice so the liquid wouldn't overwhelm the meat, but otherwise the flavors were great. Serve with tortillas, seasoned black beans, rice and homemade pico for a great meal.
This is a fantastic recipe! I've made it three times now because my family keeps asking for it!!
My family and I loved this. I turned down the pressure cooker to 45 minutes since it was on hi. Best yet!

I will make this one again! It was a hit at our NYE party this year. I did change the orange juice for chicken broth, and I also seared the pieces of pork in the instant pot first. After searing I added enough broth to whisk the bits off the pan, added the meat, then onions and garlic, then remainder of the broth. I turn it all a bit then cooked as prescribed. It was very good!
We loved it for both Lumpia meat and Enchilada Meat. I feel that we could have left the liquid in the Instant Pot and used it for a 2nd batch, as the smell of the orange juice was great.

I’ve belonged to Allrecipes for years and never written a review, but I feel I must with this one- it was absolutely amazing. I followed the recipe exactly, but did shorten the time to 50 minutes with a 15 minute natural release. Also- the one thing I feel is a must- line a baking sheet with foil, spray with nonstick cooking spray, then shred your pork on the baking sheet (removing any icky fatty pieces). Sprinkle about 1/4 cup of cooking juices on top. Broil on high in your oven for about five minutes. Turn or stir around, then broil a few minutes more. Gives the pork those nice crispy edges.

I had a 3lb pork shoulder so I used half the recommended amount of spices and orange juice. I cooked for an hour and that’s it. It is juicy, flavorful and shredded super easy. This is only my second time using my instantpot and I am so happy with this.
The flavor is phenomenal!

This was AWESOME!! I made this just like the recipe. I did use a bone in pork butt roast. I trimmed the meat off the bone as close as possible, and added the bone to the instant pot The sauce came out wonderful.
THis receipe is so easy to make and taste great!!!!!!
Outstanding!
